{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3330843,"name":"Ben Moeller","username":"benmoeller","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/cdc98d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T04:09:46.179Z","cooked":"

My team is currently using some polyurethane belts pictured below to tie together our intake and flywheels. We have been having problems with the belts snapping when running the robot for a decent amount of time. Any ideas or things teams have done in the past to help with this or to tie flywheels going in the opposite direction together?

IMG_24383024×4032 2.54 MB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T04:09:46.179Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":325,"reads":467,"readers_count":466,"score":1718.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Ben Moeller","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/9/7/97aa1fad07c6f62076f319566aebfb038ca68e54.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59364,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3330852,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T04:23:49.988Z","cooked":"

A few questions to inform us: Are these welded, using the connectors or purchased in a loop already? How tight are you running them? How many feet per second are those belts running at?

For welded (melted together) I would anticipate not getting to temperature when pressed together. For the connectors I would expect too tight of radius on the pulley (if breaking at connector) or some weird wear from a sharp edge near the connector if breaking elsewhere. For premade I would expect weird wear.

Regardless: looks like wear from some combo of high speed and high tension. Likely the wrong belt for the job you are asking it to do. A thermal camera or feeling the belts would likely reveal they are degrading from heat.

With speed and torque comes the need for gearing and not figure 8 belts.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T04:41:04.512Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":437,"readers_count":436,"score":107.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/2","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3330858,"name":"ben gates","username":"banjogates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T04:44:41.563Z","cooked":"

Use either a twisted timing belt or a timing belt to a geared connection - far more reliable and far, far better-performing under torque.

Heavy wheels, even with the inherent slip of poly belting, will easily cause those belts to snap if they accelerate too aggressively.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T04:44:41.563Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":408,"readers_count":407,"score":91.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"ben gates","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"breh"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/3","custom_user_title":"breh","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3330864,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T04:54:04.863Z","cooked":"

Well the way I would tie two flywheels in opposite direction is a timing belt and a pair of gears, but it looks like you may have trouble implementing that without switching that entire shooter plate. Is that in the cards?

The hacky way I would work around that if I didn’t want to replace the shooter plate is to create an auxillary bearing plate for the gear shaft that indexes off the blue Spline XL shaft.

Another thought is that the wear could come from rubbing in the middle. Maybe if you put some low friction material in between it would help?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T04:56:14.011Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":394,"readers_count":393,"score":83.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/4","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3331226,"name":"Kara Bakowski","username":"Karibou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T16:42:32.636Z","cooked":"
Skyehawk:

A few questions to inform us: Are these welded, using the connectors or purchased in a loop already? How tight are you running them? How many feet per second are those belts running at?

Seconded on these questions; would also be helpful to have a source/part number (McMaster, Grainger, etc). Bonus if you have a picture of the snapped belt ends.

To add to Skye’s suggestions, for welded belts, make sure the “seam” at the weld is “clean” (smooth and with minimal protrusion from the surface of the belt). If it’s not already clean, use flush cutters to trim it until it’s closer to the diameter of the belt.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T16:42:32.636Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":312,"readers_count":311,"score":97.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Kara Bakowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her/hers"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/5","custom_user_title":"she/her/hers","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3331245,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-12T16:59:54.480Z","cooked":"

The belt shows what appears to be abrasion. I suspect it slips a lot while accelerating / decelerating the wheels. Slow that down if practical. Replace the belt often. Increase friction on the pulleys. These are suggestions if better options are not practical

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-12T17:01:59.035Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":267,"readers_count":266,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"FrankJ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15944,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/6","custom_user_title":"2974 Robot Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3331828,"name":"Ben Moeller","username":"benmoeller","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/cdc98d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T03:11:08.688Z","cooked":"

To answer some questions first I don’t know for sure what FPS we are running it at but it is pretty tight. We are running welded belts. Lastly they are the 4mm polyurethane belts from mcmaster. Also would just having two belts or a thicker belt help distribute some of the stress?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T03:11:08.688Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":218,"readers_count":217,"score":48.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Ben Moeller","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9018,"username":"Karibou","name":"Kara Bakowski","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59364,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332007,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T14:15:45.549Z","cooked":"

That material is too expensive for me to consider a consumable. How about a belt for competitions and a belt for practice (the old competition belts and run them until they break). As suggested above as a separator my team uses smooth aluminum or steel sheets or Teflon sheets (very slippery but much more expensive) if we want to divert something and need it slippery.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T14:15:45.549Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":36.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":59364,"username":"benmoeller","name":"Ben Moeller","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/cdc98d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332104,"name":"Jake177","username":"Jake177","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jake177/{size}/147237_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T16:01:30.329Z","cooked":"

4mm feels very small to me for the loads from a flywheel. For polyurethane belts, our go-to has always been the orange 1/4" round belting from McMaster (https://www.mcmaster.com/59725K732). We cut it to length, undersized by ~10%, and weld it ourselves. Just make sure that you follow the minimum pulley diameter for whatever belt you use. For the 1/4" belt, the minimum recommended pulley diameter is 2".

Having said all that, a flywheel is a place I would look for an alternative solution. There’s no real way to control slipping with these belts, and that can add uncontrolled variation to your trajectory. If it’s possible for you to replace this belt with a timing belt or chain, and add a gear mesh to get the shafts rotating in opposite directions, that would be my suggestion. If that’s not a feasible solution for you, I’d recommend going up to 1/4" diameter belt on 2" diameter pulleys at the very least.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T16:01:30.329Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":34.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Jake177","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/59725K732","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1653,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332109,"name":"Kara Bakowski","username":"Karibou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T16:03:30.331Z","cooked":"

Was typing pretty much all of this and you beat me to it.

Only other thing I have to add is that while I’m not super familiar with the green textured belts, I wonder if they may be too grippy, so they stick and break instead of slip when the load becomes too high.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T16:03:30.331Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":26.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Kara Bakowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1653,"username":"Jake177","name":"Jake177","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jake177/{size}/147237_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her/hers"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/10","custom_user_title":"she/her/hers","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332111,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T16:09:20.501Z","cooked":"

I also see that as a very skinny belt, ESPECIALLY for something working hard. Spooling flywheels up and down is HARD work…

When welding PU belts, you -really- need to wait, wait, wait for it to cool before doing anything else. A full minute is sensible. If you move it around hot you compromise the strength!

Also, use a temperature controlled heating device; a temperature controlled soldering iron is a decent solution. DO NOT try to do this with a 500F blazing hot soldering iron… crispy critter…

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T16:11:30.471Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":25.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/11","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332119,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T16:21:43.992Z","cooked":"

Are they coming apart at the welded joint or someplace else?

One suggestion: Bring spare belts to a competition. Put “Check urethene belts for wear and replace if showing wear” on your return-to-pit checklist. (Or just replace them every X matches." – after every match, put a line on them with sharpie. After 3 lines, replace the belt.)

Don’t have a “return-to-pit checklist”? Every team should – that’s where you put your "check that all the screws are tight, that your wheels still spin and haven’t worn down, that none of your electrical connections have come disconnected, and that no wires have worked their way into gearboxes.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T16:21:43.992Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":458376,"topic_slug":"polyurethane-belts-breaking","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/polyurethane-belts-breaking/458376/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3332221,"name":"Nick Aarestad","username":"cadandcookies","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cadandcookies/{size}/158154_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T17:57:48.960Z","cooked":"

On the subject of 6mm vs 4mm polycord, it’s worth noting that welds of this sort are strong partially based on the surface area being welded together. If you are butt welding them, that means that a 6mm cord has over twice the surface area being welded than a 4mm cord, and the weld is proportionally stronger.
